title.value: Artificial Intelligence for Detection of Dementia Using Motion Data: A Scoping Review
title.justification: The title is directly mentioned at the beginning of the paper.
title.quote: Artificial Intelligence for Detection of Dementia Using Motion Data: A Scoping Review

extractions.description: This paper is a scoping review focused on identifying and evaluating AI interventions for the detection of dementia using motion data. The review comprehensively examines studies deploying AI methods to analyze motion sensor data, highlighting gaps in current research and suggesting future directions.

type.justification: The paper is a scoping review that assesses existing empirical studies on AI-based interventions for dementia detection using motion data.
type.quote: The review followed the framework proposed by O’Malley’s and Joanna Briggs Institute methodological guidance for scoping reviews.

name.justification: The paper discusses the application of AI technologies in medicine, specifically for detecting dementia.
name.quote: Artificial intelligence (AI) is defined by John McCarthy as “the science and engineering of making intelligent machines,” and has become an integral part of medicine, both in detection and treatment.

name.justification: The specific application area of the paper is the detection of dementia using AI technologies.
name.quote: The objective of this study was to identify and evaluate AI interventions for detection of dementia using motion data.

name.justification: The paper mentions the use of a recurrent neural network for achieving high accuracy in one study.
name.quote: The best score of 96%, came from a study that used a recurrent NN.

is_contributed.justification: The model is cited in relation to an existing study and not as a contribution of the paper itself.
is_contributed.quote: The best score of 96%, came from a study that used a recurrent NN.

is_executed.justification: There is no indication that this model was executed within the scope of this review paper.
is_executed.quote: The best score of 96%, came from a study that used a recurrent NN.

is_compared.justification: The model is mentioned in relation to its performance but not in a comparative context within this review paper.
is_compared.quote: The best score of 96%, came from a study that used a recurrent NN.

referenced_paper_title.value: Deep convolutional neural networks and transfer learning for measuring cognitive impairment using eye-tracking in a distributed tablet-based environment
referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced study title is provided in the context of different AI methods used in dementia detection.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Deep convolutional neural networks and transfer learning for measuring cognitive impairment using eye-tracking in a distributed tablet-based environment.

name.value: Logistic Regression and Random Forest Hybrid Model
name.justification: The paper mentions a hybrid model using logistic regression and random forest achieving high performance.
name.quote: The best score of 0.96 AUC came from a study that used logistic regression and RF model.

is_contributed.justification: This model is cited from an existing study, not developed within the paper.
is_contributed.quote: The best score of 0.96 AUC came from a study that used logistic regression and RF model.

is_executed.justification: The execution of this model is discussed in an external study, not within this paper.
is_executed.quote: The best score of 0.96 AUC came from a study that used logistic regression and RF model.

is_compared.justification: The model is reported for its performance metrics but not compared within the review.
is_compared.quote: The best score of 0.96 AUC came from a study that used logistic regression and RF model.

referenced_paper_title.value: Dementia scale score classification based on daily activities using multiple sensors
referenced_paper_title.justification: The paper discusses AI methods similar to the hybrid model in relation to assessing dementia.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Dementia scale score classification based on daily activities using multiple sensors.

name.value: Emory Healthy Brain Study/Goizueta Alzheimer’s Disease Research Center data
name.justification: The dataset was one of the most common private datasets used in the studies referenced by the paper.
name.quote: The most commonly used datasets were private datasets (n = 9, 45%), and the two most common types of private data were the Emory Healthy Brain Study/Goizueta Alzheimer’s Disease Research Center data (n = 2, 22%).

referenced_paper_title.value: Artificial Intelligence for Detection of Dementia Using Motion Data: A Scoping Review
referenced_paper_title.justification: The paper mentions the dataset in the context of dataset usage across various studies in the review.
referenced_paper_title.quote: The most commonly used datasets were private datasets (n = 9, 45%), and the two most common types of private data were the Emory Healthy Brain Study/Goizueta Alzheimer’s Disease Research Center data (n = 2, 22%).

name.value: Oregon Center for Aging and Technology database
name.justification: This dataset is highlighted as one of the common private datasets in studies discussed in the paper.
name.quote: ...and the Oregon Center for Aging and Technology database (n = 2, 22%).

referenced_paper_title.value: Artificial Intelligence for Detection of Dementia Using Motion Data: A Scoping Review
referenced_paper_title.justification: Mentioned within the paper among datasets frequently used for similar studies.
referenced_paper_title.quote: ...and the Oregon Center for Aging and Technology database (n = 2, 22%).
